awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Trabecular and cortical skeletal correlates to locomotor ontogeny in hominoids
awd_abstract_narration:
The growth and development of the human skeleton is affected by the way it is used across the life course.  In order to understand how human skeletal development evolved, it is useful to study skeletal development in other closely related primates. The goal of this doctoral dissertation project is to investigate how changes in locomotion across the chimpanzee life course are reflected in the skeleton. Chimpanzees change from moving mostly in the trees when they are young to moving more on the ground as they age, providing an opportunity to examine how chimpanzee trabecular (spongy) and cortical (compact) bone are modified as locomotion changes across the life course. The research will contribute to our understanding of bone biology, specifically the sensitivity of the skeleton to changes in movement throughout life, which can be used to better reconstruct the locomotion of extinct fossil apes and humans, particularly the evolution of terrestriality. This research will be used in K-12 science outreach and exhibited at natural history museums. CT scans and 3D prints of Pan troglodytes and fossil hominoids (apes) will also be part of an international exhibit focused on ape evolution and conservation. All CT scans generated from this project will be shared with the museums where the data were collected, furthering scientific access and inquiry. 

Bones are a crucial source of data from the fossil record because they undergo modification in response to the mechanical loads placed upon them during movement (e.g. walking, running, climbing). However, most studies to date focus on either trabecular or cortical bone and not the two together in one study. Chimpanzees modify how they move through their life, shifting from more arboreal to more terrestrial substrates from infancy to adulthood. Thus, if the skeleton is responding to these changes, the investigators hypothesize that these transitions will be detectable in trabecular and cortical bone. This study will also address whether both bone types respond to locomotor changes during development, and will apply these findings to other species, extant and fossil, to help in recovering patterns of movement and substrate usage. These questions will be addressed using microCT scans of trabecular bone in the fore- and hindlimb as well as pQCT scans of cortical bone in the shaft of the femur, tibia, humerus, and radius. The prediction is that trabecular and cortical bone at each life history stage will reflect the locomotor behaviors used at that time. By further studying the relationship between ontogenetic changes in behavior and cortical and trabecular bone structure, novel anatomical proxies sensitive to loading patterns may be identified and used to reconstruct the locomotor repertoires of fossil apes and humans.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this study was to determine whether trabecular and cortical bone respond to changes in substrate use and positional behavior from infancy through adulthood, using chimpanzees as a model. Traits that are correlated with shifts in behavior and substrate were identified in chimpanzees and then tested through complementary comparative analyses of the postcrania of gorillas (which are more terrestrial) and orangutans (which are more arboreal). There were three main research tasks: (1) Assess the degree of plasticity vs. developmental constraint on trabecular and cortical bone in the skeleton by determining when and how trabecular and cortical bone change through ontogeny in response to locomotor change in chimpanzees. (2) Compare the transitions in cortical bone found in chimpanzees with orangutans and gorillas, who bracket chimpanzees in their proportion of arboreal and terrestrial behavior. This comparison allowed the determination of the suites of cortical traits that characterize arboreal vs. terrestrial locomotion (mobility). (3) Comparative data from this study was used to reconstruct locomotion in the fossil hominoid taxa, Morotopithecus bishopi and Proconsul major. Data analysis of this task is ongoing, and will not be reported on here. 

The first research task was to assess the effect of chimpanzee locomotor development on the amount and structure of the inner spongey (trabecular) bone at the end of limb bones, and compare changes in the trabecular bone with the cortical bone (the hard outside bone, predominately in the shaft). Results from the trabecular bone were found to be more limited than expected. However, changes in locomotion over time did effect the structure of the cortical bone in the shafts of the limb bones. It was expected that (1) as individuals aged their trabecular bone would become more oriented (degree of anisotropy) following a single main plane of loading, (2) the relative volume (bone volume divided by total volume) would increase more in the forelimbs during younger ages while the relative bone volume would be greater in the hindlimbs as the individuals aged, (3) cortical bone would correlate strongly with these changes in trabecular bone. We found that the orientations of the trabeculae and relative trabecular bone volume did not match the predictions of the study and did not follow age matched changes in locomotion. These results indicate that cortical bone tends to be a better predictor of locomotor variability compared to trabecular bone across life history. There was no effect of age on the rate of strength increase in either the forelimb or hindlimb, indicating a more consistent change in bone volume and strength independent of locomotion. There were no significant correlations between midshaft cortical and proximal trabecular bone in the femur or humerus across ontogeny. These results showed that cortical and trabecular bone have differential responsiveness to ontogenetic locomotor changes, and that the degree of plasticity of each bone type is different. This is extremely useful when trying to understand the locomotion of subadult ape fossils, and how we can use trabecular and cortical bone to accurately reflect the locomotor repertoire of these subadults.

The second research task was to understand how the cortical bone morphology in chimpanzees compared to the morphology of two closely related species: gorillas and orangutans. The goal was to study if there were suites of cortical bone features that consistently were found in more arboreal taxa/ periods of ontogeny and conversely features more associated with terrestrial taxa/periods of ontogeny. Results indicated that proportions of arboreal and terrestrial locomotion was detectable in the midshaft of the femur and humerus in chimpanzees, gorilla, and orangutans. The relative strength of the femur and humerus were consistent with age related mobility changes and were consistent with species specific levels of arboreal/terrestrial locomotion. This was the most informative feature, in combination with the relative ellipticity of the bones (circularity or ellipticity of a bone shaft). However, the relative ellipticity of the midshaft became less indicative of specific locomotor patterns in adults. Orangutans and gorillas had similar midshaft ellipticities and direction of this ellipticity, though they use different locomotor styles and substrates. It is likely that there was a convergence in morphology from the direction of shear strain in both species. These results will be useful in providing a wider comparative data set to more accurately reconstruct the locomotion of fossil hominins, whose proportion of arboreal and terrestrial locomotion is debated. Additionally, the inclusion of orangutans within the study offers more insight into the skeletal development of the taxa, since orangutans are typically underrepresented within skeletal studies of primates. These results were used as part of two public museum presentations at the University of Michigan Museum of Natural History Museum, and an online presentation for middle school students in the Detroit area. These presentations focused on how activity and lifestyle can impact bone formation and development in humans and non-human apes.
